questions.text: What is the most common tumour of the cerebellopontine angle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acoustic neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma):

  • It's a benign slow slow-growing tumour of the 8th nerve. It is the most common tumour of the cerebellopontine angle.
  • The most common site of origin is the Inferior Vestibular division of the 8th
  • It is common in the 4th-5th decade.
  • It is mostly unilateral except in Neurofibroma-2 (bilateral vestibular schwannoma)
  • Ear examination is normal.

Explanation of other options:

Meningioma(Option B): The Second most common CPA tumour.

Glomus tumour (Option C): Rare in the CPA; more common in the temporal bone or jugular bulb. It is the most common tumour of the middle ear.

Cholesteatoma(Option D): Typically affects the middle ear and mastoid, not primarily a CPA tumour.

questions.text: The roll-over phenomenon is seen in.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The roll over phenomenon is classically seen in the retrocochlear lesions, the speech discrimination score initially increases, but later falls even on further increasing the loudness.
  • Acoustic neuroma is a classical example of retrocochlear hearing loss, whereas Meniere's disease, BPPV, and labyrinthine fistula are classical examples of cochlear lesions(Other options ruled out).
  • Speech audiometry - the discrimination score is very poor in retrocochlear and poor in cochlear hearing loss.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old mechanical engineer has presented to an outpatient clinic with the complaint of right-sided hearing loss and tinnitus. These symptoms have been troubling him for the last year. The hearing loss is progressive. The ear examination of the patient is normal. MRI Brain shows space-occupying lesions at the right cerebellopontine angle.

Which of the following is the earliest clinical finding that can be detected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is most likely a case of vestibular schwannoma. The trigeminal Nerve(CN V) is most commonly involved after CN VIII.
  • This presents as absent corneal reflex(due to reduced corneal sensitivity)(first clinical finding to appear), numbness or paraesthesia of the face.
  • It develops in the Internal acoustic meatus from the inferior division of the vestibular nerve.
  • Motor weakness of the facial nerve is a late feature of this tumour and is not common, as the motor division of the facial nerve is thicker and has a longer intracranial course, which allows it to be stretched without producing facial weakness(Option A ruled out).
  • The sensory division of the facial nerve(= Nerve of Wrisberg) is thin and hence easily compressed by the tumour. This leads to loss of sensation in the posterosuperior part of the external auditory canal(Hitzelberger sign). But it is not the earliest feature(Option D ruled out)

questions.text: The best Radiological investigation to diagnose Acoustic Neuroma is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The best radiological investigation for Acoustic neuroma is Gadolinium-enhanced MRI, because:

  • It provides excellent soft tissue detail.
  • It shows tumour size, location, and relationship with adjacent structures.
  • It helps differentiate the tumour from surrounding tissues.

Other investigations are:

  • PTA-unilateral SNHL.
  • Tone decay- faster.
  • SDS (speech discrimination score)- poor (40%)
  • The roll-over phenomenon is positive.
  • BERA-delayed wave V. (The latency of wave V will be increased.)

Explanation of incorrect options:

Plain CT Brain(Option A): Poor soft tissue contrast; may miss small tumours.

Plain MRI Brain(Option B): Better than CT, but without contrast, small tumours might be missed.

Contrast-enhanced CT Brain(Option C): Better than plain CT but still inferior to MRI for soft tissue resolution.

choices.text: Neurosurgical removal by middle cranial fossa approach

questions.text: A 73-year-old person with mild unilateral sensorineural hearing loss on the right side has been diagnosed with ipsilateral Acoustic neuroma on Gadolinium-enhanced MRI scan. The tumour size mentioned in the radiologist's report is 1.0 cm. Audiogram reveals mild SNHL on the right side. What is the further management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Since the tumour size is small and the age of the patient is 73, it will be appropriate to go for Gamma Knife therapy, a stereotactic radiotherapy.

Indications for Gamma Knife Therapy:

  • The patient is unwilling to undergo surgery
  • Patient unfit for surgery
  • Old patient with a small tumour with residual hearing.

Approach to the surgery:

  • The middle cranial fossa approach is preferred for small tumours with residual hearing. It will lead to hearing preservation. If this patient had been young, we would have gone for Option D.
  • The translabyrinthine approach is good for large-sized tumours with no residual hearing. Hearing preservation is not possible in this. Option C ruled out.
